posts.name: Uddish Sood
posts.cooked: We have a 1/2 inch hex that we want to put a bolt all the way through. The shaft is however a little too long, and, even after tapping through both sides, we couldn’t put a bolt through. How can we tap all the way through the hex shaft.

posts.name: REV Robotics Co-founder & CEO
posts.cooked:
from one side of the shaft use a drill bit larger than the major dimeter of the threads. Drill down until you reach the threads on the other end.  The issue you are seeing is that anywhere that isn’t tapped is actually smaller than the bolt.

I don’t know the exact application for this, but I suspect you don’t need the hex shaft to be fully threaded.

posts.name: snichols
posts.cooked:
How long is your shaft, and why does it need to be tapped all the way through? My usual answer to my students would be “find another way”.

Can you instead use a smaller diameter bolt and have it go straight through without engaging the threads? Can you tap each end just a little, and put a bolt on each side?

We need it to go all the way through bc it needs to screw into a surface on the other end of the shaft. We could do that but there would still be no way to finish the tap and have the bolt go all the way through.
We do need it to go through and screw into the surface on the other end of the shaft. And drilling through still wont solve the issue of our taps not being long enough to carve all the way through.

posts.name: tkchan
posts.cooked: you can find a thread rod from your local hardware store - depending on thread size, etc.  but I know I have gotten 10-32 3’ long before from Homedepot.  Alternative is to rethink your mounting position (if possible).

posts.custom_user_title: think outside of the box from time to time

posts.name: Crystal
posts.cooked:
eli-ass:

We need it to go all the way through bc it needs to screw into a surface on the other end of the shaft.

If you need it to thread into another surface, why does the standoff have to be threaded? Would the mechanism still work if the shaft just had a clearance hole?

A picture might be helpful here.
That is probably our best option. The screw in hole is deep enough to keep it stable too. Thanks man.

posts.name: Jon Stratis
posts.cooked:
CIM:

A picture might be helpful here.

I would echo this.  Instead of focusing on how to achieve a specific solution, a full description of the problem may give us a better chance of offering a solution that would work best.

posts.name: Chris Herzog
posts.cooked:
Putting a stud in the end of the shaft like it seems you’re doing is the typical way it’s done downtown.  Some stud locker (Loctite Red or Green if you really want to be serious) is a good solution.

Drilling long holes all the way through shafts is not a trivial thing - most engineers will go to great lengths to avoid doing that…

posts.cooked: Unless you are in possession of a gun drill and a gun drilling machine at least.

posts.name: sanddrag
posts.cooked:
This will get you deeper. You need to go through from one side only. https://www.mcmaster.com/2582A491/

I’m with everyone above though, you should design it differently.

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked: Also, as a reference for anyone in the future: Tapping holes from both sides and hoping the threads will meet in the middle is a recipe for disappointment.  Not only do both holes have to be totally centered on the shaft and square, the starting threads must be clocked so they meet perfectly in the middle.  If you don’t have a seriously dialed-in lathe, good luck with that. (I’m assuming that as you said “tapped” that you don’t.)  Even if you managed to get the bore hole lined up perfectly, getting threads cut from both sides to line up is definitely harder.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
GeeTwo:

Also, as a reference for anyone in the future: Tapping holes from both sides and hoping the threads will meet in the middle is a recipe for disappointment.

I was reading through this thread boggling at the fact that no one had mentioned this…

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: If you really want the bolt to go all the way through AND thread into the shaft, tap one end as deep as is reasonable, and drill in the other end with a clearance hole… Bob’s yer uncle!

posts.name: Jon Stratis
posts.cooked:
Richard_Wallace:

Wait, are you saying we should go to great lengths to avoid holes that go to great lengths?

I must be doing something wrong then… we’ve got two drill bits, about 1-foot long each, for clearance holes for both 10-32 and 1/4-20 bolts

Granted, it’s generally used for things like match-drilling bumper mounting holes, where you’ve got a big old bumper in the way of drilling through some normal stuff, but it’s still a fun drill bit to use!

posts.name: Richard Wallace
posts.cooked:
Why yes, I do have a 5/16" drill that is a foot long.  Why do you ask?
